VOL. XVIII, NO. 13.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WILLARD THE NEW TRUSTEE

MUSICIANS JOURNEY TO TOME

HIGH POST FOR DR. HOLLANDER

PRACTICE MEET GREAT SUCCESS

Succeeds William H.Buckler on Governing Board of University—Is President
of the Baltimore and Ohio R. R.

They Play Basketball in Afternoon, and
Score a Great Success at Night.
Tome Boys Appreciative.

Rumors from Washington Say President
Wilson Wants Him to Serve on
Federal Reserve Board.

Four Cage Records Go in First Track
Contest Hopkins Victorious Over
Y. M. C. A. by Large Score.

At the meeting of the Board of
Trustees last Tuesday, President
Daniel Willard of the Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad was unanimously elected a trustee of the University. Mr. Willard succeeds Dr.
William H. Buckler the noted archaeologist who, at one time, was
considered the probable next president of the University.
Dr. Buckler resigned from the
Board two years ago, when he went
abroad to carry on archaeological
investigation in Asia.
Owing to the fact that he has
kept in constant touch with Hopkins matters, and although absent,
has done much for the advancement
of the University, the place had not
been filled.
A committee, consisting of Dr.
William H. Welch, chairman of
the Board of Administration; R.
Brent Keyser, chairman of the
Board of Trustees, and B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., called on Mr. Willard
several weeks ago and urged him
to accept the Hopkins trusteeship.
As Mr. Willard wrote his letter of
acceptance last week, the meeting
of the trustees was'merely in the
nature of a formal ratification of
his acceptance.
Mr.. Keyser said that Mr. Willard's acceptance was a source of
great gratification to him and the
other members of the Board. He
regards Mr. Willard as a strong
acquisition.
Dean Griffin also expressed this
gratification at the selection of such
a talented executive as Mr. Willard for the position of trustee of
the University.
•
The new trustee is a man of the
highest intellectual and executive
abilities. He is a self-made man
in the highest sense of the word,
having risen to his present high
position from the humble position
of section foreman. He has always
been a close personal friend of Dr.
\Velch and Mr. Keyser, and the
consequent close touch with the
aims and ideals of the University
has aroused in him a very keen interest in its future. Mr. Willard,
though a comparatively young railroad president, was very recently
chosen by his colleagues to represent all the railroad systems of the
East at the recent rate, hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The University Musical Clubs
made a trip to Port Deposit last
Saturday, and gave a concert there
in Memorial Hall of the Tome
School. The following men made
the trip: Messrs. White, Hayes,
Eiseman, Bowden, Scovell, Spieker,
Supplee, Snyder, Rutledge, Weber,
Melamet, Stollenwerck, Primrose,
Hall, Weech, Lynch, Smith, Geissel,
Howell, Doub, Gailey, Baker, Biser,
Reier, Lauchheimer, Owens, Coblentz, Bacchus, Gillet, Fulton and
E. L. R. Smith. Leaving Baltimore
about one o'clock, the musicians arrived at Tome in time to play a very
amateurish basketball game with
the Tome team. Our men had no
practice and of course were badly
beaten. The concert at night was
given in the Memorial Hall. There
were about 3oo in the audience.
mostly boys, with some members of
the faculty and a few ladies. The
audience was, no doubt, the most
appreciative one that our men have
ever played to. It did one good
to hear them applaud; it went and
came straight from the heart. It
seemed to put new life into our
men and they gave the best concert
of this season, in spite of their depleted numbers. The quartet drew
forth thunderous applause, and
"Jack and Gill" walked away with
their usual honors. In spite of the
bad weather, the musicians all declared they had had a "large" time,
not excluding the eats.
The Tome concert has given the
Clubs excellent practice for the
McCoy Hall concert. The weak
points showed up, and the fine
points have begun to peer forth.
All that remains is for the students
to get busy with the tickets and provide just as large an audience on
February 6.
On the seventh a very limited
number of the musicians will make
a trip to Frederick, where they will
give a concert in the auditorium of
Tiood College.

Dispatches from Washington were
sent over the country yesterday telling of the rumor that President
Wilson was considering Dr. Jacob
H. Hollander, head of the economic
department, for membership on the
new Federal Reserve Board. Senator Hollis, of New Hampshire, it
was said, is believed to be Dr. Hollander's sponsor, and friends of the
professor attach more credence to
the dispatches because he and the
President have known each other
as university professors.
It is remembered that Dr. Hollander has done excellent service
for the country before in handling
the finances of Santo Domingo;
suggesting government reforms for
Cuba, and in organizing the treasury of Porto Rico when the island
was taken over by the United States
after the Spanish. war.
The rumor that he is now slated
for membership on the Reserve
Board is based on a speech delivered before the Bankers' Association of Washington on Saturday
night. Senator Hollis said in his
speech that the senate had agreed
not to suggest names for the Board
to the President, but that he had
violated the compact by suggesting
one name. He further said:
"He is a Republican, too; I consider him one of the greatest financial experts in the world. One of
the remarkable things he did was to
write an article in which he pointed
out the faults of the old banking
and currency system and predicted
that a nation-wide money panic
would result. Well, the panic came.
It seemed to me that a man so
thoroughly familiar with currency
problems would be a good man to
have on that Board."
Senator Hollis, from the point of
view of university men, is quite correct in his praise of Dr. Hollander,
but he is perhaps mistaken in calling the professor a Republican.
(Continued on page 5, col. 2)

By defeating the team of the Baltimore Y. M. C. A. to the tune of
74 to 25 in the initial meet of the
season last Saturday night, in which
four cage records were smashed,
the track men made a beginning
that prophesies a bright season for
this year. The Y. M. C. A. men
put up a good fight throughout, but.
in most cases were no match for the
collegians. The Association's star
miler, J. B. (Spike) Brown, who
established the former cage record
last year, was able to clip off a
second from his old time, completing his distance in four minutes
fifty-eight seconds.
The most interesting event was
the 440-yard dash, which Lloyd
(J. H. U.) won in record time. The
previous record established by former Capt. Herbert Catlin was 583'5
seconds, but Lloyd covered the distance in a beautiful race in 58 flat.
Groover(J. H. U.) finished second,
not far behind the winner, and
Everet (Y. M. C. A.) followed
closely. The 88o-yard run was also
a pretty race, won by Uhler(J. H.
U.) in the exceedingly good time
seconds.
of 2 minutes
Hopkins was victOrious in both
the relay events, breaking the cage
records in both. The 88o-yard relay, in which four men run each
two laps around the cage, was done
5 seconds, taking off
in I minute 387
four-fifths of a second from the old
record. Straus, Thompson, Wells
and Sutton, three of whom are
freshmen, made up this team for
Hopkins. In the r,600-yard relay
375 seconds were clipped off the
former time, Wagner, Binford,
Groover and Lloyd covering the
distance in 3 minutes 2975 seconds.
Tappan, Conolly and Iddings made
a clean sweep of the high jump for
Hopkins, the first two tying for
first place at 5 feet 44 inches.
Hildebrandt won the shot-put for
Y. M. C. A. with a put of 36 feet
4 inches. He and Brown were
7/
the only Association men to capture
first places.
There were also sonic novicc
events run off for the purpose of
giving the men on the squad, who
had not yet had an opportunity to
compete, a chance to show their
skill. In these, Steinback took first
place in the 30-yard dash; McEwen
(J. H. U.) won the 220, and Frank.
also of Hopkins, carried off the honors in the 449.
The rain prevented a crowd from
attending. This cage meet was held
before one of the poorest crowds
Hopkins men can recall.

Edward Kennard Rand, professor at the American School of
Classical Studies of the American
Academy of Rome, during the scholastic year 1912-13, will give a lecture in McCoy Hall at five o'clock
on Thursday, January 29, on the
farm of the great Roman poet,
Quintus Horatius Flaccus Horace.
The old farm is better known as
"Horace's Sabine Farm."
Professor Rand, born on December 20, 1871, in Boston, Mass.,
graduated from Harvard University
with the degree of A. B. in 1894,
and in 1895 received his A.M. He
was instructor in Latin at the University of Chicago during 1895-7
and again during the summer of
1898. He then went abroad to
Munich, where he studiecl in the
libraries of the University of Munich until 1901, at which time he
received the degree of Ph.D. Returning to America in i9o1 Professor Rand became instructor in
Latin at Harvard, and taught at
this University until 1909. In the
year 1912 he took up his duties at
the American Academy in Rome.
The lecture will cover two trips

made by Professor Rand to the
region of the farm in February,
1913, while professor at the American SchOol of Classical Studies in
Rome.

Professor Ducros' Lecture.

M. Jean Ducros, an old student
in the Normale Superieure de Paris,
one of the best known institutions
of learning in the world, and now
professor in the Normal Collcge of
New York, will give the seventh
of his series of ten lectures on "The
French Poetry After the Romanticism," at twelve o'clock on Saturday.
In the lecture M. Ducros will tell
of the changes in French poetry
after 1850, showing how the Romanticism had little by little ruined
it, and how the Parnassienne School
had been established, where the
study of ancicnt French poetry can
b2 completed.

The January meeting of the Engineering Society will be merged into
the numerous scientific lectures
which are being given during the
present month. All members are
urged to watch the bulletins.
The next regular monthly meeting will be held on Monday, February 9, at which time Dr. Gilpin,
associate professor of chemistry,
will address the Society. Dr. Gilpin will speak of the place of chemistry in engineering and of the work
of the so-called chemical engineer.
He will illustrate his lecture and
all memberS of the University are
urged to keep this date in mind,
as a treat will certainly be in store
for all who are interested in either
chemistry or engineering.
Among the men who- have been
or will be asked to speak before the
Society during the present year are
Dr. Bliss, collegiate professor of
physics; Mr. Calvin W. Hendrick,
chief engineer of the Sewerage
Commission, and Mr. Ezra B.
Whitman, chief engineer of the city
water department.
Applications for membership in
the Society may now be sent to
Secretary Leitheiser, Postoffice Box
383. All members of the University and any one else interested in
engineering, whether a member of
the Society or not, are most cordially invited to attend its regular
meetings. Only members, however,
have the privilege of the floor, the
right to vote and the right to attend
the business meetings.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 26, 1914.
Wild Rumors and the Actual Fact.

Rumors that the Board of Trustees has selected a new president
to succeed Dr. Remsen and relieve
Dr. Welch and his administrative
committee have been flying thick
and very fast during the past week.
Whispered confidences have revealed the startling information that
at last the proper executive has been
found. But they are still just plain
rumors. The trustees have not
selected the president, but they are
nearing the goal.
• Rumors that Gilman Hall will be
used next fall for lecture-rooms and
for the library have also been circulated. The magnificent new structure is practically finished, but it
will not be occupied until the laboratories and other necessary structures complete the University group
at Homewood. The new technical
building, however, is an exception.
As soon as it is turned over by the
contractors it will be fitted for instruction, and the engineering students will work there next October.
There is, unfortunately, a current
opinion that the trustees are "too
slow." Some think that a new
president should be selected at once
and -that everything should be
moved to Homewood on the day
after his inauguration. It would be
very good if this could be done
successfully, i. e., without injury to
the University. But such an action,
in the minds of the trustees, would
be folly. Hopkins is not the richest
University in the country, and its
moves, involving both finance and
policy, must be subjected to serious
forethought.
The trustees of the University,
a body both conservative and progressive, are fully aware of the fact

that delay is embarrassing, but when
the delay means betterment, as it
does in the case of Homewood and
the *president, they feel justified in
taking time.
Rumors are very funny things;
some of those concerning the new
president are actually hilarious. The
best plan for all connected with
Hopkins is that they devote the
time they employ in gossiping about
the new president to studying, and
perhaps in a few years they will be
qualified to be considered as candidates for the position themselves.
Jack Cates, Coach.

Everyone in the University is
gratified at the re-election of Mr.
Cates to the 'Varsity head-coachship. When, early last season, it
was announced that he had been
secured as advisory coach, and that
he could not devote his entire time
to the squad, it was considered a
most fortunate acquisition for the
staff. Later on in the season, however, he was induced to become
head coach, and it was felt that
much progress would be made. The
team did "pick up" materially, and
while the season was not a glowing
success, there were no persons who
laid the shortcomings of the team
or its candidates at the feet of Mr.
Cates.
The athletic leaders, the candidates for the team, and the student
body, in fact, everyone interested in
Hopkins football, were very highly
pleased with Mr. Cates as coach,
and the opinion prevailed that he
should be retained.
With his recent re-election comes
the prediction that the "very best
possible" showing will be made by
the football team next fall. This
means that Mr. Cates will get as
much out of the squad as is possible.
It now remains for the University
to provide an efficient squad. There
will have to be a campaign, such as
is made by Harvard, Yale, Virginia,
Princeton, and all other large colleges, carried on in the immediate
vicinity of Hopkins. The attractions of Hopkins, both as regards
study and sport, will have to be set
forth to promising athletes of
neighboring preparatory and high
schools. In other words, we shall
have to get more material.
Besides, interest in football must
be aroused right here in the University. The good players we now
have must be retained, and new
players must be developed.
It is not to be believed that the
Athletic Association can select one
of the very best coaches in the
country and then expect him "to
make a silk purse out of a sow's
ear."
Mr. Cates will have to be supplied with the very best material
available, and the only possible way
to bring this about is to begin right
now to recruit forces for next fall's
team.
We have the best coach Johns
Hopkins has ever had, and we shall
have the best team we ever had if
we begin now to get it together.

The opening of the second term
brings with it one of the richest
periods of lectures in the history of
the University. Dr. Adams began
last Thursday a series of lectures.
On Friday Mr. William Merritt
Chase delivered a talk on "Whistler
and Some Modern Isms," under the
auspices of the Teachers' Training
School and the School Arts League
of this city; Monday, January 27,
Dr. Shosuke Sato of the Tohake
Imperial University at Sapporo,
Japan, will begin his series of lectures on the progress which his
country has made during the past
half century.
The remaining lectures of Dr.
Sato's course will be given on Wednesday and Friday of this week,
and on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of the next. On Tuesday
of this week Dr. Adams will make
his second appearance in McCoy
Hall, while on Thursday there will
be an illustrated lecture by Dr. Edward Kennard Rand of Harvard
University, professor at the American School of Classical Studies in
the American Academy in Rome
for the year 1912-13.
For those interested in science,
a very interesting series of lectures
will be given daily this week, at
4.30 P. M., in the Physical Laboratory, by Dr. Wolfgang Ostwald.
of Berlin, on the general subject of
"Colloid Chemistry." On Monday
night, January 26, Dr. Ostwald will
speak on this subject before the
Johns Hopkins Scientific Association at the Johns Hopkins Club.
This talk will be preceded by a subscription dinner.
The following is an outline of the
0-round Dr. Ostwald will cover in
each of his five lectures in the
Physics Laboratory:
1. What are colloids? The Elements of Quantitative Colloid Analysis. Formation and Preparation
of Colloids.
2. Mechanical, optical, electrical,
and chemical properties of substances in the colloid state, classification of the colloids.
3. Changes in the colloid state.
Internal change of state, swelling,
setting, syneresis, absorption, coagulation, and peptisation.
4. Scientific applications of colloid chemistry.
5. Technical applications of colloid chemistry.

SOPHOMORE CLASS MEETING

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

Board of Editors and Managers for the
1916 "Hullabaloo" Elected—Banquet Committee Appointed.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

A most important meeting of the
class was held on last
Tuesday. The Board of Editors
and Managers for the 1916 "Hullabaloo" w.ere elected.
The Committee on Arrangements
and Nominations for the 1916 classbook was composed of the following: Tingley, chairman; Bagley,
Richardson, Woodward and Leitheiser, first submitted its report.
The substance of. this report was
that the class elect a board of ten
men—seven editors and three business managers—and that these ten
elect from their own number an
editor-in-chief and a business manager, and from the remainder of
the class an art editor by competition. This provided for a board of
eleven men. The report was adopted, but before the Committee read
the nominations the class passed
motions to the effect that the Board
should have the power to elect or
suspend members at any time that
it saw fit. The nominations of the
Committee were then. announced.
The following were elected: editors, Tingley, Leitheiser, Rutledge,
Melamet, Primrose, Spieker and
Penniman; managers, Bagley, Nelson and Johnston. They will meet
in a few days and elect the editorin-chief, business manager and art
editor.
President Bagley also appointed
the Banquet Committee, which consists of Rutledge, Wilson, Woodward, Penniman and Bagley (elected by class). They are now working up the annual feast, which will
be held the latter part of February,
and at which they expect to have
several freshmen as guests.

Hon. Charles Francis Adams' First Lecture is Well Received The Series
Instructing and Interesting.

New York and New Jersey Societies
Getting Up Volume as Homewood
Inauguration Souvenir.

The Hon. Charles Francis Adams of Boston and Washington delivered the first of his course of
eight lectures last Thursday before
a representative audience that filled
every available bit of space in McCoy Hall. The general subject of
the course is "1643-1865; a Nationality: Its Inception, Developand Birth." The first lecture was
entitled "Principia," which served
merely as an introduction to the
series.
Dr. Adams began by telling of
the series of four lectures which he
delivered under the Cecil Rhodes
Foundation at Oxford last spring.
He described the audiences he met
and some of the experiences he had
while in England and dwelt in some
detail on a correspendence he has
had with Lord Bryce on the subject. He then proceeded to bridge
the gap between himself and the
audience by giving a hasty review
of his antecedents and of his life.
After having done this, the lecturer
gave what he considered the three
main issues which resulted from the
Civil War, namely: the growth of
United States nationality, the end
of man's dominion over man and
the great impetus given to the cause
of democracy. These issues, Dr.
Adams said, he hoped to develop
fully without the usual obstacles
which generally hamper historians,
namely: religion, patriotism and political preconception.
Judging by the introductory lecture, the series gives signs of being a highly instructive and interesting one.
The remaining lectures of the
course and their dates are: Tuesday, January 27, "The Pitfall of
a Divided Sovereignty"; Thursday,
February 5, "King Cotton"; Thursday, February 12, "The Lancashire
Armageddon"; Thursday, February
19, "British Civil War Cartoons";
Thursday, February 26, "A Crisis
in Downing Street"; Thursday,
March 5, "Expende Hannibalem";
Thursday, March 12, "Vae Victis,
and Reconstruction." .

The Johns Hopkins Alumni Association of New York and New
Jersey has authorized the preparation of a catalogue of all present
and former officers and students of
the University, to be presented to
the trustees of our alma mater on
the occasion of the inauguration of
the buildings on the new site at
Homewood. In order to facilitate
the work, two cards have been sent
to all the students and alumni of
the University, with the request
that they be filled out in duplicate
and forwarded to the committee.
One of these cards will be kept in
the New York office of the committee, while the publication is in
course of preparation, and the other
will be filed with the Registrar of
the University at Baltimore.

therefore, that this work, which has
been aptly described as a "Who's
Who From J. H. U.," shall be as
nearly complete as possible, the
committee particularly requests that
special attention be given to the last
question on the cards, which asks
for information regarding any of
the former 'Hopkins men with
whom the signer may be acquainted.
The Committee in charge of this
work consists of Elgin R. L. Gould,
Ph.D. '86; Walter Hines Page, fellow '76; Charles Lane Poor, Ph.D.
'92; Albert Shaw, Ph.D. '84, and
Benjamin Tuska, A.B. '87.

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY
VOL. XVIII, NO. 13.

BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 26, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

WILLARD THE NEW TRUSTEE

MUSICIANS JOURNEY TO TOME

HIGH POST FOR DR. HOLLANDER

PRACTICE MEET GREAT SUCCESS

Succeeds William H.Buckler on Governing Board of University—Is President
of the Baltimore and Ohio R. R.

They Play Basketball in Afternoon, and
Score a Great Success at Night.
Tome Boys Appreciative.

Rumors from Washington Say President
Wilson Wants Him to Serve on
Federal Reserve Board.

Four Cage Records Go in First Track
Contest Hopkins Victorious Over
Y. M. C. A. by Large Score.

At the meeting of the Board of
Trustees last Tuesday, President
Daniel Willard of the Baltimore
and Ohio Railroad was unanimously elected a trustee of the University. Mr. Willard succeeds Dr.
William H. Buckler the noted archaeologist who, at one time, was
considered the probable next president of the University.
Dr. Buckler resigned from the
Board two years ago, when he went
abroad to carry on archaeological
investigation in Asia.
Owing to the fact that he has
kept in constant touch with Hopkins matters, and although absent,
has done much for the advancement
of the University, the place had not
been filled.
A committee, consisting of Dr.
William H. Welch, chairman of
the Board of Administration; R.
Brent Keyser, chairman of the
Board of Trustees, and B. Howell
Griswold, Jr., called on Mr. Willard
several weeks ago and urged him
to accept the Hopkins trusteeship.
As Mr. Willard wrote his letter of
acceptance last week, the meeting
of the trustees was'merely in the
nature of a formal ratification of
his acceptance.
Mr.. Keyser said that Mr. Willard's acceptance was a source of
great gratification to him and the
other members of the Board. He
regards Mr. Willard as a strong
acquisition.
Dean Griffin also expressed this
gratification at the selection of such
a talented executive as Mr. Willard for the position of trustee of
the University.
•
The new trustee is a man of the
highest intellectual and executive
abilities. He is a self-made man
in the highest sense of the word,
having risen to his present high
position from the humble position
of section foreman. He has always
been a close personal friend of Dr.
\Velch and Mr. Keyser, and the
consequent close touch with the
aims and ideals of the University
has aroused in him a very keen interest in its future. Mr. Willard,
though a comparatively young railroad president, was very recently
chosen by his colleagues to represent all the railroad systems of the
East at the recent rate, hearings before the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The University Musical Clubs
made a trip to Port Deposit last
Saturday, and gave a concert there
in Memorial Hall of the Tome
School. The following men made
the trip: Messrs. White, Hayes,
Eiseman, Bowden, Scovell, Spieker,
Supplee, Snyder, Rutledge, Weber,
Melamet, Stollenwerck, Primrose,
Hall, Weech, Lynch, Smith, Geissel,
Howell, Doub, Gailey, Baker, Biser,
Reier, Lauchheimer, Owens, Coblentz, Bacchus, Gillet, Fulton and
E. L. R. Smith. Leaving Baltimore
about one o'clock, the musicians arrived at Tome in time to play a very
amateurish basketball game with
the Tome team. Our men had no
practice and of course were badly
beaten. The concert at night was
given in the Memorial Hall. There
were about 3oo in the audience.
mostly boys, with some members of
the faculty and a few ladies. The
audience was, no doubt, the most
appreciative one that our men have
ever played to. It did one good
to hear them applaud; it went and
came straight from the heart. It
seemed to put new life into our
men and they gave the best concert
of this season, in spite of their depleted numbers. The quartet drew
forth thunderous applause, and
"Jack and Gill" walked away with
their usual honors. In spite of the
bad weather, the musicians all declared they had had a "large" time,
not excluding the eats.
The Tome concert has given the
Clubs excellent practice for the
McCoy Hall concert. The weak
points showed up, and the fine
points have begun to peer forth.
All that remains is for the students
to get busy with the tickets and provide just as large an audience on
February 6.
On the seventh a very limited
number of the musicians will make
a trip to Frederick, where they will
give a concert in the auditorium of
Tiood College.

Dispatches from Washington were
sent over the country yesterday telling of the rumor that President
Wilson was considering Dr. Jacob
H. Hollander, head of the economic
department, for membership on the
new Federal Reserve Board. Senator Hollis, of New Hampshire, it
was said, is believed to be Dr. Hollander's sponsor, and friends of the
professor attach more credence to
the dispatches because he and the
President have known each other
as university professors.
It is remembered that Dr. Hollander has done excellent service
for the country before in handling
the finances of Santo Domingo;
suggesting government reforms for
Cuba, and in organizing the treasury of Porto Rico when the island
was taken over by the United States
after the Spanish. war.
The rumor that he is now slated
for membership on the Reserve
Board is based on a speech delivered before the Bankers' Association of Washington on Saturday
night. Senator Hollis said in his
speech that the senate had agreed
not to suggest names for the Board
to the President, but that he had
violated the compact by suggesting
one name. He further said:
"He is a Republican, too; I consider him one of the greatest financial experts in the world. One of
the remarkable things he did was to
write an article in which he pointed
out the faults of the old banking
and currency system and predicted
that a nation-wide money panic
would result. Well, the panic came.
It seemed to me that a man so
thoroughly familiar with currency
problems would be a good man to
have on that Board."
Senator Hollis, from the point of
view of university men, is quite correct in his praise of Dr. Hollander,
but he is perhaps mistaken in calling the professor a Republican.
(Continued on page 5, col. 2)

By defeating the team of the Baltimore Y. M. C. A. to the tune of

season last Saturday night, in which
four cage records were smashed,
the track men made a beginning
that prophesies a bright season for
this year. The Y. M. C. A. men
put up a good fight throughout, but.
in most cases were no match for the
collegians. The Association's star
miler, J. B. (Spike) Brown, who
established the former cage record
last year, was able to clip off a
second from his old time, completing his distance in four minutes
fifty-eight seconds.
The most interesting event was
the 440-yard dash, which Lloyd
(J. H. U.) won in record time. The
previous record established by former Capt. Herbert Catlin was 583'5
seconds, but Lloyd covered the distance in a beautiful race in 58 flat.
Groover(J. H. U.) finished second,
not far behind the winner, and
Everet (Y. M. C. A.) followed
closely. The 88o-yard run was also
a pretty race, won by Uhler(J. H.
U.) in the exceedingly good time
seconds.

Tappan, Conolly and Iddings made

The rain prevented a crowd from

Edward Kennard Rand, professor at the American School of
Classical Studies of the American
Academy of Rome, during the scholastic year 1912-13, will give a lecture in McCoy Hall at five o'clock
on Thursday, January 29, on the
farm of the great Roman poet,
Quintus Horatius Flaccus Horace.
The old farm is better known as
"Horace's Sabine Farm."
Professor Rand, born on December 20, 1871, in Boston, Mass.,
graduated from Harvard University
with the degree of A. B. in 1894,
and in 1895 received his A.M. He
was instructor in Latin at the University of Chicago during 1895-7
and again during the summer of
1898. He then went abroad to
Munich, where he studiecl in the
libraries of the University of Munich until 1901, at which time he
received the degree of Ph.D. Returning to America in i9o1 Professor Rand became instructor in
Latin at Harvard, and taught at
this University until 1909. In the
year 1912 he took up his duties at
the American Academy in Rome.
The lecture will cover two trips

made by Professor Rand to the
region of the farm in February,
1913, while professor at the American SchOol of Classical Studies in

The January meeting of the Engineering Society will be merged into
the numerous scientific lectures
which are being given during the
present month. All members are
urged to watch the bulletins.
The next regular monthly meeting will be held on Monday, February 9, at which time Dr. Gilpin,
associate professor of chemistry,
will address the Society. Dr. Gilpin will speak of the place of chemistry in engineering and of the work
of the so-called chemical engineer.
He will illustrate his lecture and
all memberS of the University are
urged to keep this date in mind,
as a treat will certainly be in store
for all who are interested in either
chemistry or engineering.
Among the men who- have been
or will be asked to speak before the
Society during the present year are
Dr. Bliss, collegiate professor of
physics; Mr. Calvin W. Hendrick,
chief engineer of the Sewerage
Commission, and Mr. Ezra B.
Whitman, chief engineer of the city
water department.
Applications for membership in
the Society may now be sent to
Secretary Leitheiser, Postoffice Box
383. All members of the University and any one else interested in
engineering, whether a member of
the Society or not, are most cordially invited to attend its regular
meetings. Only members, however,
have the privilege of the floor, the
right to vote and the right to attend
the business meetings.

BALTIMORE, MD., JAN. 26, 1914.
Wild Rumors and the Actual Fact.

Rumors that the Board of Trustees has selected a new president
to succeed Dr. Remsen and relieve
Dr. Welch and his administrative
committee have been flying thick
and very fast during the past week.
Whispered confidences have revealed the startling information that
at last the proper executive has been
found. But they are still just plain
rumors. The trustees have not
selected the president, but they are
nearing the goal.
• Rumors that Gilman Hall will be
used next fall for lecture-rooms and
for the library have also been circulated. The magnificent new structure is practically finished, but it
will not be occupied until the laboratories and other necessary structures complete the University group
at Homewood. The new technical
building, however, is an exception.
As soon as it is turned over by the
contractors it will be fitted for instruction, and the engineering students will work there next October.
There is, unfortunately, a current
opinion that the trustees are "too
slow." Some think that a new
president should be selected at once
and -that everything should be
moved to Homewood on the day
after his inauguration. It would be
very good if this could be done
successfully, i. e., without injury to
the University. But such an action,
in the minds of the trustees, would
be folly. Hopkins is not the richest
University in the country, and its
moves, involving both finance and
policy, must be subjected to serious
forethought.
The trustees of the University,
a body both conservative and progressive, are fully aware of the fact

that delay is embarrassing, but when
the delay means betterment, as it
does in the case of Homewood and
the *president, they feel justified in
taking time.
Rumors are very funny things;
some of those concerning the new
president are actually hilarious. The
best plan for all connected with
Hopkins is that they devote the
time they employ in gossiping about
the new president to studying, and
perhaps in a few years they will be
qualified to be considered as candidates for the position themselves.
Jack Cates, Coach.

Everyone in the University is
gratified at the re-election of Mr.
Cates to the 'Varsity head-coachship. When, early last season, it
was announced that he had been
secured as advisory coach, and that
he could not devote his entire time
to the squad, it was considered a
most fortunate acquisition for the
staff. Later on in the season, however, he was induced to become
head coach, and it was felt that
much progress would be made. The
team did "pick up" materially, and
while the season was not a glowing
success, there were no persons who
laid the shortcomings of the team
or its candidates at the feet of Mr.
Cates.
The athletic leaders, the candidates for the team, and the student
body, in fact, everyone interested in
Hopkins football, were very highly
pleased with Mr. Cates as coach,
and the opinion prevailed that he
should be retained.
With his recent re-election comes
the prediction that the "very best
possible" showing will be made by
the football team next fall. This
means that Mr. Cates will get as
much out of the squad as is possible.
It now remains for the University
to provide an efficient squad. There
will have to be a campaign, such as
is made by Harvard, Yale, Virginia,
Princeton, and all other large colleges, carried on in the immediate
vicinity of Hopkins. The attractions of Hopkins, both as regards
study and sport, will have to be set
forth to promising athletes of
neighboring preparatory and high
schools. In other words, we shall
have to get more material.
Besides, interest in football must
be aroused right here in the University. The good players we now
have must be retained, and new
players must be developed.
It is not to be believed that the
Athletic Association can select one
of the very best coaches in the
country and then expect him "to
make a silk purse out of a sow's
ear."
Mr. Cates will have to be supplied with the very best material
available, and the only possible way
to bring this about is to begin right
now to recruit forces for next fall's
team.
We have the best coach Johns
Hopkins has ever had, and we shall
have the best team we ever had if
we begin now to get it together.

The opening of the second term
brings with it one of the richest
periods of lectures in the history of
the University. Dr. Adams began
last Thursday a series of lectures.
On Friday Mr. William Merritt
Chase delivered a talk on "Whistler
and Some Modern Isms," under the
auspices of the Teachers' Training
School and the School Arts League
of this city; Monday, January 27,
Dr. Shosuke Sato of the Tohake
Imperial University at Sapporo,
Japan, will begin his series of lectures on the progress which his
country has made during the past
half century.
The remaining lectures of Dr.
Sato's course will be given on Wednesday and Friday of this week,
and on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of the next. On Tuesday
of this week Dr. Adams will make
his second appearance in McCoy
Hall, while on Thursday there will
be an illustrated lecture by Dr. Edward Kennard Rand of Harvard
University, professor at the American School of Classical Studies in
the American Academy in Rome
for the year 1912-13.
For those interested in science,
a very interesting series of lectures
will be given daily this week, at
4.30 P. M., in the Physical Laboratory, by Dr. Wolfgang Ostwald.
of Berlin, on the general subject of
"Colloid Chemistry." On Monday
night, January 26, Dr. Ostwald will
speak on this subject before the
Johns Hopkins Scientific Association at the Johns Hopkins Club.
This talk will be preceded by a subscription dinner.
The following is an outline of the
0-round Dr. Ostwald will cover in
each of his five lectures in the
Physics Laboratory:
1. What are colloids? The Elements of Quantitative Colloid Analysis. Formation and Preparation
of Colloids.
2. Mechanical, optical, electrical,
and chemical properties of substances in the colloid state, classification of the colloids.
3. Changes in the colloid state.
Internal change of state, swelling,
setting, syneresis, absorption, coagulation, and peptisation.
4. Scientific applications of colloid chemistry.
5. Technical applications of colloid chemistry.

Board of Editors and Managers for the
1916 "Hullabaloo" Elected—Banquet Committee Appointed.

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

A most important meeting of the
class was held on last
Tuesday. The Board of Editors
and Managers for the 1916 "Hullabaloo" w.ere elected.
The Committee on Arrangements
and Nominations for the 1916 classbook was composed of the following: Tingley, chairman; Bagley,
Richardson, Woodward and Leitheiser, first submitted its report.
The substance of. this report was
that the class elect a board of ten
men—seven editors and three business managers—and that these ten
elect from their own number an
editor-in-chief and a business manager, and from the remainder of
the class an art editor by competition. This provided for a board of
eleven men. The report was adopted, but before the Committee read
the nominations the class passed
motions to the effect that the Board
should have the power to elect or
suspend members at any time that
it saw fit. The nominations of the
Committee were then. announced.
The following were elected: editors, Tingley, Leitheiser, Rutledge,
Melamet, Primrose, Spieker and
Penniman; managers, Bagley, Nelson and Johnston. They will meet
in a few days and elect the editorin-chief, business manager and art
editor.
President Bagley also appointed
the Banquet Committee, which consists of Rutledge, Wilson, Woodward, Penniman and Bagley (elected by class). They are now working up the annual feast, which will
be held the latter part of February,
and at which they expect to have
several freshmen as guests.

Hon. Charles Francis Adams' First Lecture is Well Received The Series
Instructing and Interesting.

New York and New Jersey Societies
Getting Up Volume as Homewood
Inauguration Souvenir.

The Hon. Charles Francis Adams of Boston and Washington delivered the first of his course of
eight lectures last Thursday before
a representative audience that filled
every available bit of space in McCoy Hall. The general subject of
the course is "1643-1865; a Nationality: Its Inception, Developand Birth." The first lecture was
entitled "Principia," which served
merely as an introduction to the
series.
Dr. Adams began by telling of
the series of four lectures which he
delivered under the Cecil Rhodes
Foundation at Oxford last spring.
He described the audiences he met
and some of the experiences he had
while in England and dwelt in some
detail on a correspendence he has
had with Lord Bryce on the subject. He then proceeded to bridge
the gap between himself and the
audience by giving a hasty review
of his antecedents and of his life.
After having done this, the lecturer
gave what he considered the three
main issues which resulted from the
Civil War, namely: the growth of
United States nationality, the end
of man's dominion over man and
the great impetus given to the cause
of democracy. These issues, Dr.
Adams said, he hoped to develop
fully without the usual obstacles
which generally hamper historians,
namely: religion, patriotism and political preconception.
Judging by the introductory lecture, the series gives signs of being a highly instructive and interesting one.
The remaining lectures of the
course and their dates are: Tuesday, January 27, "The Pitfall of
a Divided Sovereignty"; Thursday,
February 5, "King Cotton"; Thursday, February 12, "The Lancashire
Armageddon"; Thursday, February
19, "British Civil War Cartoons";
Thursday, February 26, "A Crisis
in Downing Street"; Thursday,
March 5, "Expende Hannibalem";
Thursday, March 12, "Vae Victis,
and Reconstruction." .

The Johns Hopkins Alumni Association of New York and New
Jersey has authorized the preparation of a catalogue of all present
and former officers and students of
the University, to be presented to
the trustees of our alma mater on
the occasion of the inauguration of
the buildings on the new site at
Homewood. In order to facilitate
the work, two cards have been sent
to all the students and alumni of
the University, with the request
that they be filled out in duplicate
and forwarded to the committee.
One of these cards will be kept in
the New York office of the committee, while the publication is in
course of preparation, and the other
will be filed with the Registrar of
the University at Baltimore.
Great difficulty is being experienced in securing a reasonably complete register of names. In order,
therefore, that this work, which has
been aptly described as a "Who's
Who From J. H. U.," shall be as
nearly complete as possible, the
committee particularly requests that
special attention be given to the last
question on the cards, which asks
for information regarding any of
the former 'Hopkins men with
whom the signer may be acquainted.
The Committee in charge of this
work consists of Elgin R. L. Gould,
Ph.D. '86; Walter Hines Page, fellow '76; Charles Lane Poor, Ph.D.
'92; Albert Shaw, Ph.D. '84, and
Benjamin Tuska, A.B. '87.

Former Editor Ill at His Home.

John Sharpe Dickinson, A.B. '13,
editor-in-chief of THE NEWS-LETTER last year, and at present a
student at the Harvard Law School,
is confined to his home at 1706 .
North Charles street with a very
severe cold.
Dickinson came home from Cambridge because of a slight illness,
and was rapidly recovering until he
caught cold. The indisposition is
doubly depressing because he may
not receive visitors. He will soon
be able to return to his work at
Harvard.
